text: Ezekiel was a prophet to the Israelites during their exile in which empire?
verseText: In the thirtieth year, in the fourth month, on the fifth day of the month, as I was among the exiles by the Chebar canal, the heavens were opened... the word of the LORD came to Ezekiel the priest, the son of Buzi, in the land of the Chaldeans by the Chebar canal...

text: What river was Ezekiel near when he received his first vision?
verseText: as I was among the exiles by the Chebar canal, the heavens were opened, and I saw visions of God.

text: In Ezekiel's first vision (Chapter 1), what did the four living creatures resemble?
options: Creatures with faces of a man, lion, ox, and eagle
verseText: As for the likeness of their faces, each had a human face. The four had the face of a lion on the right side, the four had the face of an ox on the left side, and the four had the face of an eagle.

text: What was Ezekiel commanded to eat in chapter 3, which tasted like honey?
verseText: And he said to me, “Son of man, eat whatever you find here. Eat this scroll, and go, speak to the house of Israel.”... Then I ate it, and it was in my mouth as sweet as honey.

text: Ezekiel was appointed by God to be a __________ for the house of Israel.
verseText: “Son of man, I have made you a watchman for the house of Israel. Whenever you hear a word from my mouth, you shall give them warning from me.

text: What symbolic act did Ezekiel perform to represent the siege of Jerusalem?
options: He lay on his side for many days next to a model of the city
verseText: “And you, son of man, take a brick and lay it before you, and engrave on it a city, even Jerusalem... Lie on your left side, and place the punishment of the house of Israel upon it... Then, when you have completed these, you shall lie down a second time, but on your right side, and bear the punishment of the house of Judah.

text: What vision did Ezekiel see in chapter 37 involving bones?
options: A valley full of dry bones coming to life
verseText: The hand of the LORD was upon me, and he brought me out in the Spirit of the LORD and set me down in the middle of the valley; it was full of bones... and behold, there were sinews on them, and flesh had come upon them, and skin had covered them... and breath came into them, and they lived and stood on their feet, an exceedingly great army.

text: What did the vision of the dry bones represent?
options: The resurrection of the dead at the end of time
The restoration of the whole house of Israel
verseText: Then he said to me, “Son of man, these bones are the whole house of Israel. Behold, they say, ‘Our bones are dried up, and our hope is lost; we are indeed cut off.’

text: In the latter chapters (40-48), Ezekiel sees a detailed vision of what?
options: A new Temple and the restored land
verseText: In the twenty-fifth year of our exile, at the beginning of the year, on the tenth day of the month, in the fourteenth year after the city was struck down, on that very day, the hand of the LORD was upon me, and he brought me to the city. In visions of God he brought me to the land of Israel, and set me down on a very high mountain, on which was a structure like a city to the south.

text: What is the name of the city described at the very end of Ezekiel?
verseText: The circumference of the city shall be 18,000 cubits. And the name of the city from that time on shall be, The LORD Is There.

text: Besides the four faces, what else was distinctive about the appearance of the living creatures in Ezekiel 1?
options: They had wheels within wheels covered with eyes
verseText: Now as I looked at the living creatures, I saw a wheel on the earth beside the living creatures, one for each of the four of them... their rims were full of eyes all around... When the living creatures went, the wheels went beside them...

text: Above the living creatures and the expanse, what did Ezekiel see?
options: The likeness of a throne, and upon the throne, a likeness with a human appearance
verseText: And above the expanse over their heads there was the likeness of a throne, in appearance like sapphire; and seated above the likeness of a throne was a likeness with a human appearance.

text: What title is Ezekiel frequently addressed by throughout the book?
verseText: And he said to me, “Son of man, stand on your feet, and I will speak with you.” (Used over 90 times)

text: How is the house of Israel described to Ezekiel when he is commissioned?
verseText: And he said to me, “Son of man, I send you to the people of Israel, to nations of rebels, who have rebelled against me... They are impudent and stubborn children.

text: What condition did God impose on Ezekiel's speech initially?
options: He would become mute except when God gave him a message
He could only speak in parables
verseText: And I will make your tongue cling to the roof of your mouth, so that you shall be mute and unable to reprove them, for they are a rebellious house. But when I speak with you, I will open your mouth...

text: What was the significance of Ezekiel lying on his left side for 390 days and his right side for 40 days?
options: Predicting the length of the exile
Representing the years of punishment for Israel and Judah respectively
The time it would take to rebuild the Temple
verseText: For I assign to you a number of days, 390 days, equal to the number of the years of their punishment. So long shall you bear the punishment of the house of Israel. And when you have completed these, you shall lie down a second time, but on your right side, and bear the punishment of the house of Judah. Forty days I assign you, a day for each year.

text: What unusual fuel source was Ezekiel initially told to use for baking his bread during the symbolic siege, representing defilement?
verseText: And you shall eat it as a barley cake, baking it in their sight on human dung.”

text: After Ezekiel protested, what did God allow him to use as fuel instead?
verseText: Then he said to me, “See, I assign to you cow's dung instead of human dung, on which you may prepare your bread.”

text: In Ezekiel 5, what did Ezekiel do with his shaved hair and beard?
options: Burned a third, struck a third with a sword, scattered a third to the wind
verseText: And you, son of man, take a sharp sword... pass it over your head and your beard... A third part you shall burn in the fire... a third part you shall strike with the sword... and a third part you shall scatter to the wind...

text: What did the three portions of hair represent?
options: The fate of Jerusalem's inhabitants: death by plague/famine, death by sword, scattering/exile
verseText: A third part of you shall die of pestilence and be consumed with famine among you; a third part shall fall by the sword all around you; and a third part I will scatter to all the winds...

text: In Ezekiel 8, where was Ezekiel transported in a vision?
verseText: He put out the form of a hand and took me by a lock of my head, and the Spirit lifted me up between earth and heaven and brought me in visions of God to Jerusalem, to the entrance of the gateway of the inner court that faces north...

text: What abominations did Ezekiel see occurring within the Temple complex?
options: Idolatry (Image of Jealousy, elders worshipping creatures, women weeping for Tammuz, men worshipping the sun)
verseText: And he said to me, 'Son of man, lift up your eyes now toward the north.' So I lifted up my eyes toward the north, and behold, north of the altar gate, in the entrance, was this image of jealousy... And he brought me into the inner court of the house of the LORD. And behold, at the entrance of the temple of the LORD, between the porch and the altar, were about twenty-five men, with their backs to the temple of the LORD, and their faces toward the east, worshiping the sun toward the east.

text: In Ezekiel 9, who were the executioners commanded to spare?
options: Those who sighed and groaned over the abominations (marked on the forehead)
verseText: And the LORD said to him, “Pass through the city, through Jerusalem, and put a mark on the foreheads of the men who sigh and groan over all the abominations that are committed in it.”... but touch no one on whom is the mark.

text: What did Ezekiel see happening to the glory of the LORD in chapters 10-11?
options: It departed from the Temple and the city
It was captured by the Babylonians
It hid in the Holy of Holies
verseText: And the glory of the LORD went up from the cherub to the threshold of the house, and the house was filled with the cloud, and the court was filled with the brightness of the glory of the LORD. Then the glory of the LORD went out from the threshold of the house, and stood over the cherubim. And the cherubim lifted up their wings and mounted up from the earth before my eyes as they went out, with the wheels beside them. And they stood at the entrance of the east gate of the house of the LORD, and the glory of the God of Israel was over them. Then the cherubim lifted up their wings, with the wheels beside them, and the glory of the God of Israel was over them. And the glory of the LORD went up from the midst of the city and stood on the mountain that is on the east side of the city.

text: What symbolic act did Ezekiel perform in chapter 12 to represent the exile?
options: Digging through a wall and carrying baggage out like an exile
verseText: As for you, son of man, prepare for yourself an exile's baggage, and go into exile by day in their sight... Dig through the wall in their sight, and go out through it... As I had been commanded, so I did.

text: Ezekiel 18 strongly emphasizes what principle regarding sin and judgment?
options: Children are punished for their parents' sins
Individual responsibility ('The soul who sins shall die')
verseText: Behold, all souls are mine; the soul of the father as well as the soul of the son is mine: the soul who sins shall die... The soul who sins shall die. The son shall not suffer for the iniquity of the father, nor the father suffer for the iniquity of the son.

text: What proverb were the exiles using that Ezekiel chapter 18 refutes?
options: 'The LORD helps those who help themselves'
'The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge'
verseText: “What do you mean by repeating this proverb concerning the land of Israel, ‘The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge’?

text: Ezekiel 24 uses the symbol of a boiling pot with choice pieces to represent what?
options: Jerusalem under siege, with its inhabitants trapped
verseText: ‘Set on the pot, set it on; pour in water also; put in it the pieces of meat, all the good pieces, the thigh and the shoulder... Woe to the bloody city, to the pot whose rust is in it...

text: What personal tragedy did Ezekiel experience on the same day the siege of Jerusalem began, which he was forbidden to mourn publicly?
verseText: “Son of man, behold, I am about to take the delight of your eyes away from you at a stroke; yet you shall not mourn or weep, nor shall your tears run down... So I spoke to the people in the morning, and at evening my wife died.

text: Ezekiel 25-32 contains oracles against several nations. Which nation is NOT included in this section?
verseText: (Chapters cover Ammon, Moab, Edom, Philistia, Tyre, Sidon, and Egypt. Persia rises later).

text: Why was judgment pronounced against Ammon, Moab, and Edom?
options: For their malicious joy over Judah's downfall
verseText: (Ammon said 'Aha!' over the sanctuary; Moab said Judah is like other nations; Edom acted vengefully).

text: The extended oracle against Tyre (Ezekiel 26-28) compares the city to what?
verseText: (Chapter 27 details Tyre's extensive trade and resources using the allegory of a well-built ship that sinks).

text: What sin is the Prince of Tyre specifically condemned for in Ezekiel 28?
options: Pride ('I am a god, I sit in the seat of the gods')
verseText: “Son of man, say to the prince of Tyre, Thus says the Lord GOD: “Because your heart is proud, and you have said, ‘I am a god, I sit in the seat of the gods, in the heart of the seas,’ yet you are but a man, and no god...

text: The lament over the King of Tyre in Ezekiel 28:12-19 uses imagery reminiscent of what?
options: The fall of Satan or Adam in Eden
verseText: You were in Eden, the garden of God; every precious stone was your covering, sardius, topaz, and diamond, beryl, onyx, and jasper, sapphire, emerald, and carbuncle; and crafted in gold were your settings and your engravings. On the day that you were created they were prepared. You were an anointed guardian cherub. I placed you; you were on the holy mountain of God; in the midst of the stones of fire you walked. You were blameless in your ways from the day you were created, till unrighteousness was found in you. In the abundance of your trade you were filled with violence in your midst, and you sinned; so I cast you as a profane thing from the mountain of God, and I destroyed you, O guardian cherub, from the midst of the stones of fire. Your heart was proud because of your beauty; you corrupted your wisdom for the sake of your splendor. I cast you to the ground; I exposed you before kings, to feast their eyes on you.

text: Pharaoh, king of Egypt, is compared to what creature in Ezekiel 29?
options: A great sea monster (crocodile) lying in the Nile
verseText: Speak, and say, Thus says the Lord GOD: “Behold, I am against you, Pharaoh king of Egypt, the great dragon that lies in the midst of his streams, that says, ‘My Nile is my own; I made it for myself.’”

text: In Ezekiel 33, Ezekiel's role as a watchman is reaffirmed. What is his responsibility?
options: To warn the wicked and the righteous
verseText: So you, son of man, I have made a watchman for the house of Israel. Whenever you hear a word from my mouth, you shall give them warning from me... if you warn the wicked to turn from his way, and he does not turn... you have delivered your soul.

text: Who does Ezekiel 34 condemn for failing to care for God's flock?
verseText: “Son of man, prophesy against the shepherds of Israel, prophesy, and say to them, even to the shepherds, Thus says the Lord GOD: Ah, shepherds of Israel who have been feeding yourselves! Should not shepherds feed the sheep?

text: Who does God promise will shepherd His flock in the future (Ezekiel 34:23)?
verseText: And I will set up over them one shepherd, my servant David, and he shall feed them: he shall feed them and be their shepherd.

text: What does God promise to give Israel in Ezekiel 36, replacing their heart of stone?
options: A heart of flesh, a new heart, and a new spirit
verseText: And I will give you a new heart, and a new spirit I will put within you. And I will remove the heart of stone from your flesh and give you a heart of flesh.

text: Why does God say He will restore Israel (Ezekiel 36:22, 32)?
options: For the sake of His holy name, which Israel profaned
verseText: “Therefore say to the house of Israel, Thus says the Lord GOD: It is not for your sake, O house of Israel, that I am about to act, but for the sake of my holy name, which you have profaned among the nations to which you came... It is not for your sake that I will act, declares the Lord GOD; let that be known to you.

text: In the vision of dry bones (Ezekiel 37), what brings the bones together and covers them with flesh?
verseText: So I prophesied as I was commanded. And as I prophesied, there was a sound, and behold, a rattling, and the bones came together, bone to its bone. And I looked, and behold, there were sinews on them, and flesh had come upon them, and skin had covered them.

text: What brings the revived bodies to life in Ezekiel 37?
verseText: Then he said to me, “Prophesy to the breath; prophesy, son of man, and say to the breath, Thus says the Lord GOD: Come from the four winds, O breath, and breathe on these slain, that they may live.” So I prophesied as he commanded me, and the breath came into them, and they lived...

text: What symbolic act did Ezekiel perform with two sticks in chapter 37?
options: He joined them together as one stick
verseText: “Son of man, take a stick and write on it, ‘For Judah, and the people of Israel associated with him’; then take another stick and write on it, ‘For Joseph (the stick of Ephraim) and all the house of Israel associated with him.’ And join them one to another into one stick, that they may become one in your hand.

text: What did the joining of the two sticks represent?
options: The joining of heaven and earth
The reunification of the divided kingdoms of Judah and Israel/Ephraim
The union of God and man
verseText: say to them, Thus says the Lord GOD: Behold, I am about to take the stick of Joseph... and I will join with it the stick of Judah, and make them one stick... and I will make them one nation in the land...

text: Who is Gog of Magog, described in Ezekiel 38-39?
options: A future enemy leader who attacks restored Israel
verseText: “Son of man, set your face toward Gog, of the land of Magog, the chief prince of Meshech and Tubal, and prophesy against him and say, Thus says the Lord GOD: Behold, I am against you, O Gog...

text: What is the ultimate outcome of Gog's invasion against Israel?
options: Israel makes a treaty with Gog
God utterly defeats Gog and his armies, revealing His holiness
verseText: (Describes God's fury, earthquake, pestilence, bloodshed, fire, and sulfur destroying Gog's forces) ... “So I will make my holy name known in the midst of my people Israel... and the nations shall know that I am the LORD, the Holy One in Israel.

text: How long will Israel spend burying the dead after Gog's defeat?
verseText: For seven months the house of Israel will be burying them, in order to cleanse the land.

text: In Ezekiel's vision of the new Temple (Chapters 40-42), who guides him and takes measurements?
options: A man whose appearance was like bronze, with a linen cord and measuring reed
verseText: When he brought me there, behold, there was a man whose appearance was like bronze, with a linen cord and a measuring reed in his hand. And he was standing in the gateway.

text: What does Ezekiel see returning to the new Temple in chapter 43?
options: The Shekinah glory of the LORD
verseText: And behold, the glory of the God of Israel was coming from the east... the earth shone with his glory... As the glory of the LORD entered the temple by the gate facing east, the Spirit lifted me up and brought me into the inner court; and behold, the glory of the LORD filled the temple.

text: Which gate of the new Temple complex was to remain shut? Why?
options: The north gate; it was unclean
The south gate; reserved for priests
The east gate; because the glory of the LORD had entered through it
The west gate; it faced away from the city
verseText: Then he brought me back to the outer gate of the sanctuary, which faces east. And it was shut. And the LORD said to me, “This gate shall remain shut; it shall not be opened, and no one shall enter by it, for the LORD, the God of Israel, has entered by it. Therefore it shall remain shut.

text: Who are the primary priests serving in Ezekiel's visionary Temple?
verseText: “But the Levitical priests, the sons of Zadok, who kept the charge of my sanctuary when the people of Israel went astray from me, shall come near to me to minister to me.

text: What flows out from under the threshold of the Temple in Ezekiel 47?
options: A river that grows deeper and brings life wherever it goes
verseText: Then he brought me back to the door of the temple, and behold, water was issuing from below the threshold of the temple toward the east... And wherever the river goes, every living creature that swarms will live...

text: What effect does the river from the Temple have on the Dead Sea?
options: It makes the water fresh and full of fish
verseText: And he said to me, “This water flows toward the eastern region and goes down into the Arabah, and enters the sea; when the water flows into the sea, the water will become fresh. And wherever the river goes, every living creature that swarms will live, and there will be very many fish.

text: What grows on the banks of the river flowing from the Temple?
options: Trees whose leaves are for healing and fruit for food
verseText: And on the banks, on both sides of the river, there will grow all kinds of trees for food. Their leaves will not wither, nor their fruit fail... their fruit will be for food, and their leaves for healing.”

text: How is the land divided among the tribes in Ezekiel's final vision?
options: In parallel strips from east to west, with a central portion for the prince, priests, and Temple
verseText: (Describes the holy district ('terumah') and the tribal allotments north and south of it).
